climbs.name: Slabtastically Fun
climbs.fa: John Knight, Keith Noback, Jacob Israel, Tim Morgan May/June 2020

content.description: Must love slab! A whole lot of fun, crimpy, and sometimes insecure moves. Sustained series of 5.10- slab moves.
content.protection:
P1- 5 bolts. 5.9+/5.10a. Might be harder for shorter people. Step up the easy slab, clip a few bolts then step up to the slippery slab and make an insecure but well protected move through the lower sugar band. Good practice for P2. Work your way up to the limestone band and place a couple small/medium pieces. Step up high and clip a bolt. Make a balancey insecure move to a big rail and eventually a big pocket high and right. Clip one more bolt and then step up to the anchor.

 P2- 13 (yes, 13!) bolts plus a #1 and #2 Camalot for the top out move. Seems like a lot of bolts until you find yourself making insecure, slabby moves and you're happy it's generously bolted. With another 5 or 6 long draws I'm sure you could probably run these pitches together.
content.location: Left (west) side of the Fun Ship. You'll need to do either the 5.7 Fun Approach pitch or the direct 5.9/10a pitch. If you do the 5.7 Fun Approach pitch you can TR the 5.9/10a pitch of P1.

content.description: A fun 5.8/5.9 bolted route with some trad protection. Follow the holes and big steps up to a short finger-sized crack. Place a few small pieces (I placed a 0.3 BD Cam) and step up onto a small shelf/shoulder. IMPORTANT NOTE - some people get lost when they step onto the shelf because you can't see the anchor. Look for a bolt on the shelf, right and just below the limestone band. The anchor is above the limestone band just above the small bush. Work your way right, clip the last bolt and then place a small cam (or two) then head up through the limestone band. I placed a #1 BD Cam. Rap the route to get down. When rapping, be sure to stay left of the giant, spooky loose flake (see pic). If you knocked this off it would be a "belayer slayer" for sure. Unfortunately, the flake happens to be in the fall line.
content.protection: Mostly bolted. Bring 8 or 9 draws and a few pieces in the 0.3 to 2” range.
content.location: Get your way to the east end of the Fun Ship by following the Thunder Mt. Trail then turn left at a large drainage and head straight up to the "Prow" of the Ship. Start the climb at the base of the pine tree.

climbs.name: Fun With Social Distancing
climbs.fa: John Knight, Ben Friedman, Iain Macdonald, Ian Ahoula

content.description: A excellent moderate and mega safe first lead for climbers who are trying to escape COVID-19. A crux at the midpoint leads to a mantle on the slanting dihedral. The bolts are practicing social distancing at 6 feet apart. Good Fun.Note - a couple people got on the Fun Police (5.10+) thinking they were on Fun with Social Distancing. Oops. Look carefully from the base. If it looks harden than 5.7 you're on the wrong route! Off the top three top-rope options exist (Fun TR #1-3), give them a shot!
content.protection: 9 bolts to lower-offs. More experienced leaders can skip a few bolts.
content.location: Directly to the left of a Hole lotta fun. This climb starts left of the big pine tree. The climb directly above the tree is Hole Lotta Fun (5.8+) and the climb right of the tree is Fun Police (5.10+).

content.description: Great distraction if the rope is set up in-between hole lotta fun and Fun with Social Distancing
content.protection: Shares the same anchors as the other TR routes
content.location: In-between hole lotta fun and Fun with Social Distancing

content.description: Good clean rock on sustained slab leading to the anchors of Fun With Social Distancing. This route required very little cleaning compared to other routes at the fun ship.
content.location: To the right of Fun TR #1

content.description: Thin moves through the alcove leading to a tricky slab section. Shares anchors with Fun With Social Distancing.
content.protection: TR off the chains on Fun With Social Distancing
content.location: Starts in the alcove, see photos for precise location.

climbs.name: Fun TR #0
climbs.fa: Like this matters. It’s just a Top Rope.

content.description: Fun top rope between Fun Approach and Flaky Fun. Use the Fun Appriach anchors and head straight up the slab and up through the limestone band. Might be 5.7 or 5.8 depending on which way you go.
content.location: Between Fun Approach and Flaky Fun. Use the Fun Approach anchor and climb straight up the fall line.

content.description: Tricky opening moves lead to easier, but sustained climbing. The crux comes up high on a slab. Don’t let this move police your fun!
content.protection: 13 bolts and a small piece of gear for the limestone band. FA was done with a 65m rope. A 60 may work.
content.location: Route is climbers right and slightly below the obvious pine tree.

content.description: Another fun addition. We’ve top roped this plenty of times and decided it would make a fun lead route. Includes some high stepping, a mantle move and a fun (but short) climb through the limestone. Goes up to the obvious cave feature. Anchors are high and right and can be reached while standing in the cave (unless you're vertically challenged). There are two options through the limestone band. The left version is a bit easier. I thought it was a bit harder than Flaky Fun and Hole Lotta Fun. It depends on whether you're comfortable with mantles and high steps. In terrible style, I flopped onto the mantle like a beached whale. Fortunately, there's no video evidence so I can deny it ever happened. I hope you enjoy this new addition. Please let me know your thoughts on the grade. And let me know if you also had to flop onto the mantle!
content.protection: 4 draws. You’ll need some small gear to get through the limestone. A 0.5 and #2 BD Camelot should do it.
content.location: This is the next route left of Fun with Social Distancing. And right of Flakey Fun. Starts just right of the bush. I added it to the topo on the main area page (which is starting to get a bit busy).

content.description: Fun little 5.7 approach with an optional 2nd pitch of 5.10b slab climbing (listed separately). Clip bolt one on the easy slab, then step up and place a small cam to work your way through the limestone band. Head up big steps and move right past 3 bolts to anchors. Rap/lower from anchor or continue up the harder slab above.
content.protection: 4 bolts and one 0.75 cam. You'll need one or (maybe two) finger sized cams to get through the limestone band.
content.location: Starts at the far left end of the Fun Ship at the base of the easy (5.3) slab. Look for big holes and the first bolt about 10' up the slab.

climbs.name: Flaky Fun
climbs.fa: Iain Macdonald, John Knight, Ben Friedman

content.description: Another excellent moderate at the fun ship. Philosophers, academics, scholars and professors spent weeks debating the grade for flaky fun. We settled on somewhere in between 5.7 and 5.9. Get on it and decide for yourself.Passing the crux at the top of the slab leads to a limestone band. An optional .5 or a 1 camalot will slot perfectly in the band leading to a final bolt and then to lower-off's.
content.location: Start just past the toprope routes to the left.

content.protection: Draws, lots of them. Bring 13 and a 0.4 camalot to get through the limestone band.
content.location: Work your way up the gully until it ends at the far (east) end of the Fun Ship. Look for the first bolt about 10' (or 15') up. You can traverse in from the right and pre-clip the first bolt then lower back to the deck for the full route experience.

content.description: South facing, ship-like feature with a 15 minute approach. If you hike slow! Route grades range from 5.7 to 5.10+. Most of the routes finish above the limestone band (except Fun with Social Distancing). You will want a few small to medium cams to get safely through the band. The lead routes are pretty clean but you'll want to use caution if you stray to the sides and top rope. Be sure to bring your helmet!Just a reminder that you will tear off holds if you climb this when it's not fully dry. Rule of thumb is to wait 2 full, dry days after a big rainstorm. Please respect this rule to ensure future climbers have the same holds to pull on.
